Claim: Six coronavirus cases confirmed in Wichita, Kansas.
Explaination: No cases were confirmed there, and claim came from non-credible websites.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Six coronavirus cases confirmed in Wichita, Kansas.

Explanation:No cases were confirmed there, and claim came from non-credible websites.

https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3471725-fake-news-breaking-news-six-coronavirus-cases-confirmed-in-wichita-kansas.html

Claim: Video shows a WHO official inappropriately touching a female attendee during a briefing session in China about the novel coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan. Same video was also used with another claim that the man is an Australian politician.
Explaination:
Video was taken out of context. The man in the video is a 2006 Nobel Prize laureate in physics, Professor George Smoot, not someone from WHO or a politician.
The clip shows Smoot attending a business conference in Julu County in Hebei Province in China in June 2018 with his significant other who was having a sore back at the time.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Video shows a WHO official inappropriately touching a female attendee during a briefing session in China about the novel coronavirus outbreak in Wuhan. Same video was also used with another claim that the man is an Australian politician.

Explanation:Video was taken out of context. The man in the video is a 2006 Nobel Prize laureate in physics, Professor George Smoot, not someone from WHO or a politician. The clip shows Smoot attending a business conference in Julu County in Hebei Province in China in June 2018 with his significant other who was having a sore back at the time.

https://medium.com/annie-lab/false-this-video-does-not-show-a-who-official-touching-a-female-conference-attendee-in-china-1da782cd49e4

Claim: Photo shows coffins from coronavirus outbreak in Italy.
Explaination: Old photo from African migrants who died from shipwreck in 2013.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Photo shows coffins from coronavirus outbreak in Italy.

Explanation:Old photo from African migrants who died from shipwreck in 2013.

https://hoax-alert.leadstories.com/3472038-Fact-Check-Photo-Does-NOT-Show-Coffins-Of-Dozens-Of-COVID19-Victims.html

Claim: Denmark passed from 200 new cases of COVID-19 in one day to only 26 cases.
Explaination: These numbers are not in line with the national authorities, it was never reported 200 or 26 news cases in one day in Denmark. On March 19, there were 75 new cases in the country.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Denmark passed from 200 new cases of COVID-19 in one day to only 26 cases.

Explanation:These numbers are not in line with the national authorities, it was never reported 200 or 26 news cases in one day in Denmark. On March 19, there were 75 new cases in the country.

https://observador.pt/factchecks/fact-check-a-dinamarca-passou-de-200-para-26-novos-casos-de-coronavirus-num-so-dia/

Claim: Claim that an American soldier was intentionally spreading the novel coronavirus in Wuhan during the seventh CISM Military World Games in October 2019 with a video clip of a man purportedly smearing saliva on the handrail on a train.
Explaination: The video is authentic but it was taken in Brussels, Belgium, on March 10, 2020. The man is not an American. According to media reports, the man was arrested by the police on the same day.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: Claim that an American soldier was intentionally spreading the novel coronavirus in Wuhan during the seventh CISM Military World Games in October 2019 with a video clip of a man purportedly smearing saliva on the handrail on a train.

Explanation:The video is authentic but it was taken in Brussels, Belgium, on March 10, 2020. The man is not an American. According to media reports, the man was arrested by the police on the same day.

https://medium.com/annie-lab/misleading-this-video-does-not-show-an-american-soldier-spreading-saliva-in-wuhan-a1ee9b7b816

Claim: Over 200 doctors in Italy die every day due to coronavirus.
Explaination: The total number of doctors in Italy who died due to the coronavirus is 66 as of Thursday, April 2.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Over 200 doctors in Italy die every day due to coronavirus.

Explanation:The total number of doctors in Italy who died due to the coronavirus is 66 as of Thursday, April 2.

https://www.rappler.com/newsbreak/fact-check/256791-doctors-die-daily-italy-due-coronavirus

Claim: Empty hospital lots and waiting rooms are indicative of a coronavirus hoax.
Explaination: No evidence cited, no authorities interviewed and didn't go into hospitals.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Empty hospital lots and waiting rooms are indicative of a coronavirus hoax.

Explanation:No evidence cited, no authorities interviewed and didn't go into hospitals.

https://leadstories.com/hoax-alert/2020/04/Fact-Check-COVID-19-Is-NOT-A-Hoax-Proven-By-Empty-Hospital-Lots-Waiting-Rooms.html

Claim: A train carrying vaccines with the inscription “COVID-19.”
Explaination: Content seems to be digitally edited, and there is no inscription on that location on such trains.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A train carrying vaccines with the inscription “COVID-19.”

Explanation:Content seems to be digitally edited, and there is no inscription on that location on such trains.

https://observers.france24.com/fr/20200318-train-stocke-vaccin-covid-19-attention-intox-coronavirus

Claim: Image with the narration to claim that a huge number of Muslims were roaming in Beruwala City in Sri Lanka during curfew, risking the lives of many amid COVID-19
Explaination: The image was from a large Muslim procession held in March 2019.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Image with the narration to claim that a huge number of Muslims were roaming in Beruwala City in Sri Lanka during curfew, risking the lives of many amid COVID-19

Explanation:The image was from a large Muslim procession held in March 2019.

https://srilanka.factcrescendo.com/2020/03/30/fact-check-a-year-old-image-being-shared-as-recent-from-beruwala/

Claim: An image with human body figurines in a bowl that claims China is serving human baby soup in its restaurants.
Explaination: The image is of an art installation to raise awareness about the rampant killing of sharks.
Label: False
html:
Claim: An image with human body figurines in a bowl that claims China is serving human baby soup in its restaurants.

Explanation:The image is of an art installation to raise awareness about the rampant killing of sharks.

https://www.boomlive.in/fake-news/2015-photo-falsely-shared-as-amit-shah-visiting-covid-19-patients-7380?check=2

Claim: Photo shows Italians prostrating themselves and praying to Allah, during the coronavirus crisis.
Explaination: The photo is from a Christian prayer vigil in Lima, Peru, on the night of 6 and 7 December 2019. It has nothing to do with the coronavirus, and doesn't show Italians converted to Islam.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Photo shows Italians prostrating themselves and praying to Allah, during the coronavirus crisis.

Explanation:The photo is from a Christian prayer vigil in Lima, Peru, on the night of 6 and 7 December 2019. It has nothing to do with the coronavirus, and doesn't show Italians converted to Islam.

https://africacheck.org/fbcheck/no-video-of-vigil-in-peru-before-coronavirus-not-italians-praying-for-forgiveness/

Claim: Photo shows a man wearing a “government issued Saint Laurent hazardous materials suit.”
Explaination: The image was posted by a self-described parody account.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Photo shows a man wearing a “government issued Saint Laurent hazardous materials suit.”

Explanation:The image was posted by a self-described parody account.

https://www.politifact.com/factchecks/2020/mar/03/viral-image/photo-florida-intern-hazmat-suit-due-coronavirus-p/

Claim: 5G exposure/radiation pollution compromises the structure and function of hemoglobin in cells and worsens COVID-19 pandemic.
Explaination: Wireless communications use electromagnetic waves to transfer data. Electromagnetic waves carry energy that is proportional to their frequency and can interact with biological tissues. However, the energy level and the penetration depth of the type of waves used for 5G do not allow them to alter the structure and function of important biological macromolecules such as hemoglobin. In addition, there is no correlation between the very limited 5G coverage in the world and the progression of the COVID-19 pandemic.
Label: Incorrect
html:
Claim: 5G exposure/radiation pollution compromises the structure and function of hemoglobin in cells and worsens COVID-19 pandemic.

Explanation:Wireless communications use electromagnetic waves to transfer data. Electromagnetic waves carry energy that is proportional to their frequency and can interact with biological tissues. However, the energy level and the penetration depth of the type of waves used for 5G do not allow them to alter the structure and function of important biological macromolecules such as hemoglobin. In addition, there is no correlation between the very limited 5G coverage in the world and the progression of the COVID-19 pandemic.

https://healthfeedback.org/claimreview/conspiracy-theorists-claim-that-5g-increases-vulnerability-to-covid-19-with-baseless-theory-that-it-affects-hemoglobin/

Claim: U.S. President Donald Trump or presidential candidate Joe Biden referred to the novel coronavirus pandemic as a time when “people are dying that have never died before.”
Explaination: This is false; there is no record of either man saying this, and letters from Ernest Hemingway show the phrase can be traced to the famed US author.
Label: False
html:
Claim: U.S. President Donald Trump or presidential candidate Joe Biden referred to the novel coronavirus pandemic as a time when “people are dying that have never died before.”

Explanation:This is false; there is no record of either man saying this, and letters from Ernest Hemingway show the phrase can be traced to the famed US author.

https://factcheck.afp.com/hemingway-phrase-misrepresented-trump-and-biden-statement-covid-19-death-toll

Claim: A photo shows the newly built hospital in Wuhan.
Explaination: The viral image was taken from an online listing and is actually a modular apartment building.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: A photo shows the newly built hospital in Wuhan.

Explanation:The viral image was taken from an online listing and is actually a modular apartment building.

https://www.newschecker.in/article/news-detail/275_14679223

Claim: A photo shows a Japanese medical professional providing aid in Wuhan.
Explaination: This photo has circulated in reports about a Japanese medical team travelling to China in 2008.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A photo shows a Japanese medical professional providing aid in Wuhan.

Explanation:This photo has circulated in reports about a Japanese medical team travelling to China in 2008.

http://u.afp.com/japanmedicalteam

Claim: Website link in order to activate 100 GB Free Internet Data & Rs.500 Talk time offer amid the COVID19 situation in Sri Lanka.
Explaination: All these are fake messages with redirects to bogus or malicious websites.
Label: FALSE
html:
Claim: Website link in order to activate 100 GB Free Internet Data & Rs.500 Talk time offer amid the COVID19 situation in Sri Lanka.

Explanation:All these are fake messages with redirects to bogus or malicious websites.

https://srilanka.factcrescendo.com/english/fact-check-fake-messages-with-100-gb-free-internet-data/

Claim: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.
Explaination: This video is of riots that happened in Peckham, London. With the help of Google search, we found several global media reports on the London riots. It was clear from these reports that the video viral on social media is the London riots that happened in 2011.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Riots in London due to the unavailability of food items. The United Kingdom will be locked down by tonight. Army soldiers take to the UK streets.

Explanation:This video is of riots that happened in Peckham, London. With the help of Google search, we found several global media reports on the London riots. It was clear from these reports that the video viral on social media is the London riots that happened in 2011.

https://www.newschecker.in/article/news-detail/275_15320709?check=2

Claim: People queue in Singapore for Halal food.
Explaination: They are queuing for masks.
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: People queue in Singapore for Halal food.

Explanation:They are queuing for masks.

https://factcheck.afp.com/video-has-circulated-reports-about-people-queuing-masks-singapore-after-novel-coronavirus-outbreak

Claim: Police asked shops selling alcohol to restrict opening hours on St. Patrick’s Day to lower the risk of house parties where coronavirus could be spread.
Explaination: Police make an annual request of shops not to sell alcohol before 4pm on St Patrick's Day - but it has nothing to do with coronavirus
Label: Misleading
html:
Claim: Police asked shops selling alcohol to restrict opening hours on St. Patrick’s Day to lower the risk of house parties where coronavirus could be spread.

Explanation:Police make an annual request of shops not to sell alcohol before 4pm on St Patrick's Day - but it has nothing to do with coronavirus

https://jrnl.ie/5049770

Claim: Coronavirus dies at a temperature above 26-27 degrees Celsius as per UNICEF.
Explaination: The viral message on novel coronavirus is NOT issued by UNICEF.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Coronavirus dies at a temperature above 26-27 degrees Celsius as per UNICEF.

Explanation:The viral message on novel coronavirus is NOT issued by UNICEF.

https://www.vishvasnews.com/english/health/fact-check-this-viral-message-on-novel-coronavirus-is-not-issued-by-unicef/

Claim: The UNHCR said ‘migrants and illegals’ in Malaysia were resisting COVID-19 testing.
Explaination: The claim is false; UNHCR officials in Malaysia said the alleged statement is fake and condemned the erroneous claim for stoking “unnecessary fear and distrust”.
Label: False
html:
Claim: The UNHCR said ‘migrants and illegals’ in Malaysia were resisting COVID-19 testing.

Explanation:The claim is false; UNHCR officials in Malaysia said the alleged statement is fake and condemned the erroneous claim for stoking “unnecessary fear and distrust”.

https://factcheck.afp.com/unhcr-condemns-fake-notice-which-claimed-refugees-malaysia-are-resisting-covid-19-tests

Claim: A post has been shared on Facebook, Twitter and Whatsapp claims a regional government in India has recommended that the juice of bitter gourd, a vegetable often used in traditional medicine, is an effective treatment for the novel coronavirus.
Explaination: The claim is false; Indian authorities dismissed the claim, calling it “absolutely false”; health experts said there is no evidence the vegetable is an effective remedy for COVID-19.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A post has been shared on Facebook, Twitter and Whatsapp claims a regional government in India has recommended that the juice of bitter gourd, a vegetable often used in traditional medicine, is an effective treatment for the novel coronavirus.

Explanation:The claim is false; Indian authorities dismissed the claim, calling it “absolutely false”; health experts said there is no evidence the vegetable is an effective remedy for COVID-19.

https://factcheck.afp.com/indian-health-authorities-refute-myth-juiced-vegetables-can-cure-covid-19

Claim: A man is allegedly selling medical masks for 80 denars on a bus owned by the Skopje Public Transportation Enterprise.
Explaination: After a short investigation, it was found out that the photo has already been posted on other sites, such as the Facebook page of the site 3minute.net, where the photo was posted on 25 February. According to the status, the photo was taken in the town of Craiova, Romania, and not in Skopje, North Macedonia.
Label: False
html:
Claim: A man is allegedly selling medical masks for 80 denars on a bus owned by the Skopje Public Transportation Enterprise.

Explanation:After a short investigation, it was found out that the photo has already been posted on other sites, such as the Facebook page of the site 3minute.net, where the photo was posted on 25 February. According to the status, the photo was taken in the town of Craiova, Romania, and not in Skopje, North Macedonia.

https://truthmeter.mk/the-man-selling-medical-masks-was-photographed-in-romania-not-on-a-bus-in-skopje/

Claim: Gargling with hot water cures coronavirus, says a doctor from Mumbai’s COVID-19 hospital.
Explaination: Gargling with water does not cure or prevent coronavirus, and this is not the doctor from the Mumbai hospital but a Tik Tok video with a pre-recorded video clip.
Label: False
html:
Claim: Gargling with hot water cures coronavirus, says a doctor from Mumbai’s COVID-19 hospital.

Explanation:Gargling with water does not cure or prevent coronavirus, and this is not the doctor from the Mumbai hospital but a Tik Tok video with a pre-recorded video clip.

https://www.boomlive.in/tiktok-video-on-coronavirus-goes-viral-as-doctor
